Class Features

Spellcasting

You draw on the primal magic of nature and Lurline's ancient gift.

Cantrips

At 1st level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the Lurlinite spell list. You learn additional cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column.

Preparing and Casting Spells

The Lurlinite table shows how many spell slots you have. To cast one of your Lurlinite spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of Lurlinite spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the Lurlinite spell list. When you do so, choose a number of Lurlinite spells equal to your Wisdom modifier + your Lurlinite level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

Spellcasting Ability

Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your Lurlinite spells, since your magic draws upon your attunement to nature and Lurline's blessing.

  • Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
  • Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier

Ritual Casting

You can cast a Lurlinite spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

Spellcasting Focus

You can use a druidic focus as a spellcasting focus for your Lurlinite spells.

Sacred Circle

At 1st level, you choose to identify with a sacred circle: Circle of the Green, Circle of the Moon, or Circle of Liberation. Your choice grants you features at 1st level and again at 2nd, 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

Lurline's Gift

Also at 1st level, your connection to Lurline grants you the ability to speak with beasts and understand their responses. You gain the ability to comprehend and verbally communicate with beasts. Additionally, Animals can always understand you, even if Silenced or otherwise unable to speak.

Wild Shape

Starting at 2nd level, you can use your action to magically assume the shape of a beast that you have seen before. You can use this feature twice. You regain expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

Your Lurlinite level determines the beasts you can transform into, as shown in the Beast Shapes table. At 2nd level, for example, you can transform into any beast that has a challenge rating of 1/4 or lower that doesn't have a flying or swimming speed.

Beast Shapes

LevelMax CRLimitationsExample
2nd1/4No flying or swimming speedWolf
4th1/2No flying speedCrocodile
8th1—Giant Eagle

You can stay in a beast shape for a number of hours equal to half your Lurlinite level (rounded down). You then revert to your normal form unless you expend another use of this feature. You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn. You automatically revert if you fall unconscious, drop to 0 hit points, or die.

Ability Score Improvement

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Timeless Body

Starting at 18th level, the primal magic that you wield causes you to age more slowly. For every 10 years that pass, your body ages only 1 year. Additionally, you suffer none of the frailty of old age, and you can't be aged magically.

Beast Spells

Beginning at 18th level, you can cast many of your Lurlinite spells in any shape you assume using Wild Shape. You can perform the somatic and verbal components of a Lurlinite spell while in beast form, but you aren't able to provide material components.

Archdruid

At 20th level, you can use your Wild Shape an unlimited number of times. Additionally, you can ignore the verbal and somatic components of your Lurlinite spells, as well as any material components that lack a cost and aren't consumed by a spell. You gain this benefit in both your normal shape and your beast shape from Wild Shape.

Sacred Circles

Circle of the Green

"The land remembers what the church would have us forget."

The Circle of the Green draws power from the living land of Oz itself—the ancient forests of Gillikin, the wild steppes of the Vinkus, even the gardens and parks within cities. They believe that the land itself is sacred, imbued with Lurline's original magic, and that protecting nature is protecting the source of all life and magic in Oz.

Bonus Cantrip

When you choose this circle at 1st level, you learn one additional Lurlinite cantrip of your choice.

Natural Recovery

Starting at 2nd level, you can regain some of your magical energy by sitting in meditation and communing with nature. During a short rest, you choose expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than half your Lurlinite level (rounded up), and none of the slots can be 6th level or higher. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

Circle Spells

Your connection to the land grants you access to certain spells. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to circle spells.

Once you gain access to a circle spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain a circle spell that doesn't appear on the Lurlinite spell list, the spell is nonetheless a Lurlinite spell for you.

Lurlinite LevelSpells
3rdbarkskin, spider climb
5thcall lightning, plant growth
7thdivination, freedom of movement
9thcommune with nature, tree stride

Land's Sanctuary

Beginning at 6th level, when you are in a natural environment, beasts and plant creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls against you. Additionally, you can move through nonmagical difficult terrain made of plants without expending extra movement and without taking damage from thorns, spines, and similar hazards.

Nature's Ward

When you reach 10th level, you can't be charmed or frightened by elementals or fey, and you are immune to poison and disease.

Nature's Sanctuary

When you reach 14th level, creatures of the natural world sense your connection to nature and become hesitant to attack you. When a beast or plant creature attacks you, that creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your Lurlinite spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature must choose a different target, or the attack automatically misses. On a successful save, the creature is immune to this effect for 24 hours.

Circle of the Moon

"In the beast form, we find our truest selves."

Circle of the Moon Lurlinites have a special kinship with Animals and believe that the barrier between human and beast consciousness is artificial, imposed by the Unionist Church for political reasons. They can take animal forms more powerful than other Lurlinites, and many work directly with the Animal Resistance.

Combat Wild Shape

When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you gain the ability to use Wild Shape on your turn as a bonus action, rather than as an action. Additionally, while you are transformed by Wild Shape, you can use a bonus action to expend one spell slot to regain 1d8 hit points per level of the spell slot expended.

Circle Forms

The rites of your circle grant you the ability to transform into more dangerous animal forms. Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Wild Shape to transform into a beast with a challenge rating as high as 1 (you ignore the Max CR column of the Beast Shapes table, but must abide by the other limitations there).

Starting at 6th level, you can transform into a beast with a challenge rating as high as your Lurlinite level divided by 3, rounded down.

Primal Strike

Starting at 6th level, your attacks in beast form count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

Elemental Wild Shape

At 10th level, you can expend two uses of Wild Shape at the same time to transform into an air elemental, an earth elemental, a fire elemental, or a water elemental.

Thousand Forms

By 14th level, you have learned to use magic to alter your physical form in more subtle ways. You can cast *alter self* at will.

Circle of Liberation

"Where there is oppression, Lurline calls us to resist."

Circle of Liberation Lurlinites are activist-priests who see their faith as inseparable from the struggle for justice. They hide Animals from Unionist inquisitors, smuggle the persecuted along the Animal Underground Railroad, heal the wounded, and strike back against tyranny. This circle is unique to Oz's political situation.

Bonus Proficiencies

When you choose this circle at 1st level, you gain proficiency with heavy armor and martial weapons.

Lurline's Shield

Starting at 1st level, your devotion to protecting the oppressed manifests as divine armor. While you aren't wearing armor, your AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

Circle Spells

Lurlinite LevelSpells
3rdaid, lesser restoration
5thbeacon of hope, revivify
7thdeath ward, guardian of faith
9thmass cure wounds, raise dead

Channel Divinity: Turn the Oppressor

At 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to utter ancient words of condemnation. As an action, you present your holy symbol, and each Unionist, government official, or creature serving an unjust authority within 30 feet of you that can see or hear you must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is turned for 1 minute or until it takes damage.

Channel Divinity: Preserve Life

Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to heal the badly injured. As an action, you present your holy symbol and evoke healing energy that can restore a number of hit points equal to five times your Lurlinite level. Choose any creatures within 30 feet of you, and divide those hit points among them. This feature can restore a creature to no more than half of its hit point maximum. You can't use this feature on an undead or a construct.

Liberation's Strike

At 6th level, when you deal damage to a creature with a weapon attack or spell attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 1d8 radiant damage. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until the start of your next turn.

Potent Spellcasting

Starting at 10th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any Lurlinite cantrip.

Lurline's Wrath

At 14th level, when an Animal or other persecuted creature you can see within 60 feet takes damage, you can use your reaction to grant them resistance to that damage and deal radiant damage to the attacker equal to your Lurlinite level. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

Multiclassing

If your campaign uses the optional multiclassing rules, here's what you need to know if you choose Lurlinite as one of your classes.

Prerequisites

To qualify for a new class, you must have a Wisdom score of 13 or higher.

Proficiencies Gained

If Lurlinite isn't your initial class, you gain proficiency with light armor, medium armor, and shields (Lurlinites will not wear metal armor or use metal shields).

Roleplaying a Lurlinite

Faith in Hiding

As a Lurlinite, you practice a forbidden religion in a land where your faith is branded heresy. You gather in secret, use code words to identify fellow believers, and constantly risk discovery. Your prayers are whispered in hidden groves, your rituals performed by moonlight in the wilderness. You may outwardly pretend to be Unionist while maintaining your true faith in secret.

Resistance and Compassion

Lurlinites tend toward compassion for the oppressed and resistance against tyranny. Many are involved in underground movements helping Animals escape persecution. Consider:

  • How public are you about your faith? Do you hide it completely?
  • What drew you to Lurlinism over the official Unionist church?
  • How do you feel about Unionists? Are they all oppressors, or can some be redeemed?
  • What would you sacrifice to protect an Animal from persecution?

Lurlinite Backgrounds

Lurlinites often come from backgrounds like Outlander, Folk Hero, Hermit, or custom backgrounds like Underground Railroad Conductor, Secret Cultist, or Animal Rights Activist.

GM Notes

Lurlinites as NPCs

Lurlinite NPCs make excellent:

  • Allies: Healers for the party, guides in wilderness areas, contacts in the Animal resistance, sources of pre-Unionist lore
  • Quest Givers: Asking the party to rescue imprisoned Animals, destroy Unionist relics desecrating sacred sites, retrieve ancient Lurlinite artifacts
  • Complications: Their association with the party might draw Unionist attention, they might ask the party to take dangerous stands against authority

The Lurlinite-Animal Connection

The close association between Lurlinites and the Animal Resistance creates natural story hooks. A Lurlinite PC might be asked to hide refugees, might discover an Animal community, or might be suspected of Animal sympathies by authorities.

Sacred Sites

Ancient Lurlinite sacred sites exist throughout Oz—stone circles in the Vinkus, hidden groves in Gillikin, underwater shrines in Quadling lakes. These can be sources of power, plot locations, or places where the veil between worlds grows thin.

character/classes/the-witch.title: The Witch
character/classes/the-witch.content:
The Witch

"Are people born wicked, or do they have wickedness thrust upon them?"

Witches are arcane spellcasters who channel magic through innate talent, dangerous pacts, or forbidden study of texts like the Grimmerie. In Oz, "witch" is both a feared title and a mark of power—from the legendary Elphaba Thropp to the countless hedge witches practicing in secret. Witches exist outside institutional magic systems, their power personal, often unpredictable, and tinged with moral ambiguity. They may be heroes, villains, or—most often—something far more complicated.

Sources of Witchcraft

Unlike Adepts who study magic academically, or Unionists who channel divine power, Witches draw magic from within themselves or through pacts with mysterious forces. Some are born with power. Others awaken it through trauma or rage. Still others trade something precious for magical gifts. The Unionist Church condemns all witchcraft as heresy, making no distinction between benevolent and malevolent practitioners.

Class Features

As a Witch, you gain the following class features.

Hit Points

  • Hit Dice: 1d6 per Witch level
  • Hit Points at 1st Level: 6 + your Constitution modifier
  • Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d6 (or 4) + your Constitution modifier per Witch level after 1st

Proficiencies

  • Armor: None
  • Weapons: Simple weapons
  • Tools: None
  • Saving Throws: Charisma, Intelligence
  • Skills: Choose two from Arcana, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Nature, Persuasion

Equipment

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a quarterstaff or (b) a dagger
  • (a) a component pouch or (b) an arcane focus
  • (a) a scholar's pack or (b) an explorer's pack
  • A spellbook (if you choose Path of the Learned), a witch's broom (nonfunctional until higher level)

Class Features

Spellcasting

Your innate magic or pact grants you the ability to cast spells.

Cantrips

At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the Witch spell list. You learn additional Witch cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column.

Spell Slots

The Witch table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your Witch spells of 1st through 9th level. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher

You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the Witch spell list. The Spells Known column shows when you learn more Witch spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the Witch spells you know and replace it with another spell from the Witch spell list.

Spellcasting Ability

Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Witch spells, since the power of your magic relies on your force of will and personality.

  • Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier
  • Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier

Spellcasting Focus

You can use an arcane focus as a spellcasting focus for your Witch spells.

Witch Path

At 1st level, choose the source of your witchcraft: the Path of Blood (innate power), Path of the Pact (bargained power), or Path of the Learned (studied power through texts like the Grimmerie). Your choice grants you features at 1st level and again at 3rd, 6th, 14th, and 18th level.

Witch Sight

Starting at 1st level, you can see magic as others see color. You can cast *detect magic* at will, without expending a spell slot. Additionally, when you see a creature casting a spell, you can use your reaction to identify the spell being cast (DC 15 + spell level Intelligence (Arcana) check).

Font of Magic

At 2nd level, you tap into a deep wellspring of magic within yourself. This wellspring is represented by sorcery points, which allow you to create a variety of magical effects.

Sorcery Points

You have 2 sorcery points, and you gain more as you reach higher levels, as shown in the Sorcery Points column (which equals your Witch level). You can never have more sorcery points than shown on the table for your level. You regain all spent sorcery points when you finish a long rest.

Flexible Casting

You can use your sorcery points to gain additional spell slots, or sacrifice spell slots to gain additional sorcery points.

  • Creating Spell Slots: You can transform unexpended sorcery points into one spell slot as a bonus action. The created spell slot vanishes when you finish a long rest. See the Creating Spell Slots table.
  • Converting Spell Slots: As a bonus action, you can expend one spell slot and gain a number of sorcery points equal to the slot's level.

Metamagic

At 3rd level, you gain the ability to twist your spells to suit your needs. You gain two Metamagic options of your choice. You gain another one at 10th and 17th level. You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted.

Metamagic Options

  • Careful Spell: When you cast a spell that forces other creatures to make a saving throw, you can protect some of those creatures from the spell's full force. To do so, you spend 1 sorcery point and choose a number of those creatures up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature). A chosen creature automatically succeeds on its saving throw against the spell.
  • Distant Spell: When you cast a spell that has a range of 5 feet or greater, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double the range of the spell. When you cast a spell that has a range of touch, you can spend 1 sorcery point to make the range of the spell 30 feet.
  • Empowered Spell: When you roll damage for a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage dice up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one). You must use the new rolls.
  • Extended Spell: When you cast a spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double its duration, to a maximum duration of 24 hours.
  • Heightened Spell: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw to resist its effects, you can spend 3 sorcery points to give one target of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell.
  • Quickened Spell: When you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the casting time to 1 bonus action for this casting.
  • Subtle Spell: When you cast a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to cast it without any somatic or verbal components.
  • Twinned Spell: When you cast a spell that targets only one creature and doesn't have a range of self, you can spend a number of sorcery points equal to the spell's level to target a second creature in range with the same spell (1 sorcery point if the spell is a cantrip).

Ability Score Improvement

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Broomflight

At 5th level, you learn to enchant a broom to serve as your flying mount. You can spend 10 minutes performing a ritual to bond with a broom. While riding your bonded broom, you have a flying speed of 50 feet. The broom has AC 15, 20 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. If it is reduced to 0 hit points, it is destroyed and you must bond with a new broom. You can have only one bonded broom at a time.

Witch Ascendant

At 20th level, your mastery of witchcraft reaches its apex. You regain 4 expended sorcery points whenever you finish a short rest. Additionally, when you roll initiative and have no sorcery points remaining, you regain 4 sorcery points.

Witch Paths

Path of Blood

"Magic runs in my veins. I was born this way."

Witches of the Path of Blood are born with power coursing through them. Perhaps your mother was touched by wild magic during pregnancy, or your bloodline carries ancient fey heritage, or—like Elphaba—you emerged green-skinned and powerful from birth. Your magic is innate, instinctive, and often tied to strong emotion.

Born of Magic

At 1st level, your connection to magic manifests physically. Choose or roll on the Witch Mark table to determine your magical appearance. Additionally, you have advantage on saving throws against spells.

Witch Mark (d6)

d6Mark
1Green skin (like Elphaba)
2Eyes that glow when casting spells
3Hair that moves of its own accord
4Shadow that doesn't match your movements
5Temperature changes around you with your emotions
6Birthmark in the shape of an arcane symbol

Empowered Magic

Starting at 3rd level, when you cast a Witch spell that deals damage, you can add your Charisma modifier to one damage roll of that spell.

Elemental Affinity

At 6th level, choose one damage type: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder. Spells you cast ignore resistance to damage of the chosen type. In addition, when you cast a spell that deals damage of that type, you can add your Charisma modifier to one damage roll of that spell.

Spell Resistance

At 14th level, you have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Overwhelming Magic

Starting at 18th level, when you cast a spell of 1st through 5th level that deals damage, you can deal maximum damage with that spell. The first time you do so, you suffer no adverse effect. If you use this feature again before you finish a long rest, you take 2d12 necrotic damage for each level of the spell, immediately after you cast it. This damage ignores resistance and immunity.

Path of the Pact

"I made a bargain. Power for a price."

You gained your magic through a pact with a powerful entity—perhaps a fey lord or lady, a devil offering temptation, the spirit of the Deadly Desert, or even the Time Dragon itself. You serve your patron's interests (willingly or not) in exchange for magical power.

Pact Magic

At 1st level, you learn two eldritch invocations of your choice from the warlock class. When you gain certain Witch levels, you gain additional invocations of your choice, as shown in the Eldritch Invocations Known table.

Patron's Gift

Also at 1st level, choose the type of entity you made your pact with. Your choice grants you a specific benefit:

  • Fey Patron: You can cast *misty step* once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to do so when you finish a short or long rest.
  • Fiend Patron: You gain resistance to fire damage and can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 120 feet.
  • Great Old One Patron: You can telepathically communicate with any creature you can see within 30 feet. You don't need to share a language, but the creature must understand at least one language.

Pact Boon

At 3rd level, your patron bestows a gift upon you. Choose one:

  • Pact of the Chain: You learn *find familiar* and can cast it as a ritual. When you cast the spell, you can choose one of the normal forms for your familiar or one special form: imp, pseudodragon, quasit, or sprite.
  • Pact of the Blade: You can use your action to create a pact weapon in your empty hand. You choose the form (any melee weapon). You are proficient with it while you wield it. This weapon counts as magical. The weapon disappears if it is more than 5 feet away from you for 1 minute or more or if you dismiss it (no action required).
  • Pact of the Tome: Your patron gives you a grimoire. Choose three cantrips from any class's spell list. While the book is on your person, you can cast those cantrips at will. They are considered Witch spells for you.

Patron's Blessing

At 6th level, your patron grants you a measure of their power. You can cast one 6th-level spell from your patron's spell list once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

Mystic Arcanum

At 14th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one 7th-level spell from the Witch spell list as this arcanum. You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

Pact Master

At 18th level, you can petition your patron for aid. You can cast *wish* once. You must finish 30 days before you can do so again. When you use this feature, your patron always twists the wish in some way—you get what you asked for, but there's always a price.

Path of the Learned

"I decoded the Grimmerie. I earned this power."

You gained your magic through study of forbidden texts—perhaps the Grimmerie itself, or copies of its pages, or other dangerous magical writings. You are a scholar of the arcane, treating witchcraft as a science to be mastered rather than an innate gift or bargained power.

Spellbook

At 1st level, you have a spellbook containing six 1st-level Witch spells of your choice. Your spellbook is the repository of the Witch spells you know, except your cantrips, which are fixed in your mind.

Preparing Spells

You prepare the list of Witch spells that are available for you to cast. To do so, choose a number of Witch spells from your spellbook equal to your Intelligence modifier + your Witch level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

Learning Spells

Each time you gain a Witch level, you can add two Witch spells of your choice to your spellbook. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. Additionally, when you find a wizard spell scroll or spellbook, you can add spells from it to your spellbook using the standard rules for learning wizard spells.

Ritual Casting

At 1st level, you can cast a Witch spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell in your spellbook. You don't need to have the spell prepared.

Arcane Recovery

At 3rd level, you have learned to regain some magical energy through study. Once per day when you finish a short rest, you can choose expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level equal to or less than half your Witch level (rounded up), and none can be 6th level or higher.

Grimmerie Secrets

At 6th level, your study of forbidden texts has unlocked secret knowledge. Choose two spells from any class's spell list. A spell you choose must be of a level you can cast, as shown on the Witch table, or a cantrip. The chosen spells count as Witch spells for you and are added to your spellbook, but don't count against the number of spells you know.

Spell Mastery

At 14th level, you have achieved such mastery over certain spells that you can cast them at will. Choose two 1st-level or 2nd-level Witch spells that are in your spellbook. You can cast those spells at their lowest level without expending a spell slot when you have them prepared.

Signature Spell

At 18th level, you gain mastery over two powerful spells and can cast them with little effort. Choose two 3rd-level Witch spells in your spellbook as your signature spells. You always have these spells prepared, they don't count against the number of spells you have prepared, and you can cast each of them once at 3rd level without expending a spell slot. When you do so, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

Multiclassing

If your campaign uses the optional multiclassing rules, here's what you need to know if you choose Witch as one of your classes.

Prerequisites

To qualify for a new class, you must have a Charisma score of 13 or higher (Intelligence 13 if Path of the Learned).

Proficiencies Gained

If Witch isn't your initial class, you gain no additional proficiencies.

Roleplaying a Witch

The Weight of the Name

In Oz, "witch" carries heavy connotations. Elphaba became the Wicked Witch of the West—but was she wicked, or was wickedness thrust upon her? Consider how your witch navigates this legacy:

  • Do you embrace the title "witch" or shy away from it?
  • How do people react when they learn what you are?
  • Are you fighting against Elphaba's dark reputation, or living up to it?
  • What's your relationship with institutional magic users like Adepts?

Moral Ambiguity

Witches in Oz exist in moral gray areas. The "Wicked" Witch fought against tyranny. The "Good" Witch Glinda enabled it. Your witch should grapple with complex ethical questions.

Witch Backgrounds

Witches often come from backgrounds like Sage (studied magic), Outlander (discovered power alone), Folk Hero (village witch), or custom backgrounds like Shiz Dropout, Grimmerie Thief, or Refugee.

GM Notes

Witches as NPCs

Witch NPCs can fill many roles:

  • Mentors: Teaching the party about magic, lending aid, providing quest hooks
  • Antagonists: Powerful enemies with personal motivations and tragic backstories
  • Wildcards: Neutral parties pursuing their own agendas, sometimes helping and sometimes hindering

The Grimmerie

The Grimmerie should be a major plot element in any campaign featuring Witches. Finding it, reading it, protecting it, or destroying it can drive entire story arcs.

Persecution and Power

Witches are both feared and hunted. The Unionist Church actively persecutes them. This creates constant tension—a Witch PC must balance using their power with remaining hidden.

Related Pages

character/classes/the-agent.title: The Agent
character/classes/the-agent.content:
The Agent

"In a police state, information is power—and I deal in both."

Agents are spies, infiltrators, assassins, and operatives navigating the Emerald City's labyrinthine politics. Whether serving the Wizard, working for resistance movements like the Gale Force, or operating as independent information brokers, Agents thrive in shadows and secrets. They excel at deception, stealth, and precision strikes—skills essential in a land where surveillance is constant and trust is rare.

Masters of Subterfuge

In Oz's authoritarian regime, Agents are everywhere. They might be Unionist inquisitors' enforcers, double agents feeding intelligence to the Animal Resistance, or freelance operatives selling secrets to the highest bidder. Whatever their allegiance, Agents understand that in Oz, the right piece of information at the right moment can topple governments or save lives.

Class Features

As an Agent, you gain the following class features.

Hit Points

  • Hit Dice: 1d8 per Agent level
  • Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
  • Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per Agent level after 1st

Proficiencies

  • Armor: Light armor
  • Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers, shortswords
  • Tools: Thieves' tools, disguise kit, one other tool of your choice
  • Saving Throws: Dexterity, Intelligence
  • Skills: Choose four from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, Stealth

Equipment

  • (a) a rapier or (b) a shortsword
  • (a) a shortbow and quiver of 20 arrows or (b) a shortsword
  • (a) a burglar's pack, (b) a dungeoneer's pack, or (c) an explorer's pack
  • Leather armor, two daggers, and thieves' tools

Class Features

Expertise

At 1st level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves' tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

At 6th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies to gain this benefit.

Sneak Attack

Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe's distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra 1d6 damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.

You don't need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn't incapacitated, and you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column.

Thieves' Cant

During your training you learned thieves' cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. It also includes a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages.

Cunning Action

Starting at 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a bonus action on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

Agent Specialization

At 3rd level, you choose a specialization: Shadow Agent or Political Operative. Your specialization choice grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

Ability Score Improvement

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1.

Uncanny Dodge

Starting at 5th level, when an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.

Evasion

Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

Reliable Talent

By 11th level, you have refined your chosen skills until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

Blindsense

Starting at 14th level, if you are able to hear, you are aware of the location of any hidden or invisible creature within 10 feet of you.

Slippery Mind

By 15th level, you have acquired greater mental strength. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws.

Elusive

Beginning at 18th level, you are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren't incapacitated.

Stroke of Luck

At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

Agent Specializations

Shadow Agent

"I am the knife in the dark, the secret that dies with its keeper."

Shadow Agents are assassins, infiltrators, and saboteurs. They excel at entering forbidden places, eliminating targets, and vanishing without a trace. Many work for the Wizard's secret police, while others serve resistance movements or operate as freelance killers.

Bonus Proficiencies

When you choose this specialization at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with the disguise kit and the poisoner's kit.

Assassinate

Starting at 3rd level, you are at your deadliest when you get the drop on your enemies. You have advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn in the combat yet. In addition, any hit you score against a creature that is surprised is a critical hit.

Infiltration Expertise

At 9th level, you can unfailingly create false identities for yourself. You must spend seven days and 25 gp to establish the history, profession, and affiliations for an identity. However, you can adopt the new identity as a disguise with the help of a disguise kit. Other creatures believe you to be that person until given an obvious reason not to.

Impostor

At 13th level, you gain the ability to unerringly mimic another person's speech, writing, and behavior. You must spend at least three hours studying these three components of the person's behavior, listening to speech, examining handwriting, and observing mannerisms.

Your ruse is indiscernible to the casual observer. If a wary creature suspects something is amiss, you have advantage on any Charisma (Deception) check you make to avoid detection.

Death Strike

Starting at 17th level, you become a master of instant death. When you attack and hit a creature that is surprised, it must make a Constitution saving throw (DC 8 + your Dexterity modifier + your proficiency bonus). On a failed save, double the damage of your attack against the creature.

Political Operative

"The pen is mightier than the sword—but blackmail is mightiest of all."

Political Operatives navigate the treacherous waters of Ozian politics, dealing in secrets, influence, and leverage. They might work for Emerald City officials, foreign powers, or themselves, always playing multiple sides against each other.

Master of Intrigue

When you choose this specialization at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with the disguise kit, the forgery kit, and one gaming set of your choice. You also learn two languages of your choice.

Additionally, you can unerringly mimic the speech patterns and accent of a creature that you hear speak for at least 1 minute, enabling you to pass yourself off as a native speaker of a particular land.

Master of Tactics

Starting at 3rd level, you can use the Help action as a bonus action. Additionally, when you use the Help action to aid an ally in attacking a creature, the target of that attack can be within 30 feet of you, rather than within 5 feet of you, if the target can see or hear you.

Insightful Manipulator

At 9th level, if you spend at least 1 minute observing or interacting with another creature outside combat, you can learn certain information about its capabilities compared to your own. The GM tells you if the creature is your equal, superior, or inferior in regard to two of the following characteristics of your choice:

  • Intelligence score
  • Wisdom score
  • Charisma score
  • Class levels (if any)

At the GM's option, you might also realize you know a piece of the creature's history or one of its personality traits, if it has any.

Misdirection

Beginning at 13th level, you can sometimes cause another creature to suffer an attack meant for you. When you are targeted by an attack while a creature within 5 feet of you is granting you cover against that attack, you can use your reaction to have the attack target that creature instead of you.

Soul of Deceit

Starting at 17th level, your thoughts can't be read by telepathy or other means unless you allow it. You can present false thoughts by making a Charisma (Deception) check contested by the mind reader's Wisdom (Insight) check.

Additionally, no matter what you say, magic that would determine if you are telling the truth indicates that you are being truthful, if you so choose, and you can't be compelled to tell the truth by magic.

Multiclassing

To qualify for a new class, you must have a Dexterity score of 13 or higher.

If Agent isn't your initial class, you gain proficiency with light armor and one skill from the class's skill list, as well as thieves' tools.

Roleplaying an Agent

Loyalty and Betrayal

As an Agent, you live in a world of shifting allegiances. Consider:

  • Who do you really serve? Is your public loyalty genuine or cover?
  • Have you ever betrayed someone? Do you regret it?
  • What lines won't you cross, even for your mission?
  • How do you maintain your sense of self when constantly lying?

The Weight of Secrets

Agents carry dangerous knowledge. In Oz's surveillance state, knowing the wrong thing can be fatal—but so can not knowing enough.

GM Notes

Agents in Oz

Oz's police state creates perfect conditions for Agent campaigns. The Wizard employs countless spies, while resistance movements need their own operatives. Every faction has Agents, and double agents are everywhere.

Information as Currency

In campaigns featuring Agents, treat information as valuable as gold. Secret documents, blackmail material, and surveillance reports can drive entire story arcs.

  • The Gale Force - Resistance operatives
  • Emerald City - Center of intrigue
  • Animal Resistance - Underground network

character/classes/the-scholar.title: The Scholar
character/classes/the-scholar.content:
The Scholar

"Knowledge is the only power that cannot be taken by force."

Scholars are researchers, historians, professors, and intellectuals who seek truth in a land where truth is dangerous. Whether studying at Shiz University, preserving forbidden texts, or documenting the atrocities the government would prefer forgotten, Scholars wield expertise as their weapon. In Oz's authoritarian regime, independent scholarship is suspect—yet knowledge remains essential for those seeking to understand or change the world.

Seekers of Truth

Scholars might specialize in magic theory, natural philosophy, history, theology, or any other field. Some work within the system at state-controlled universities. Others pursue forbidden research in hiding. All understand that in Oz, certain knowledge can get you killed—yet they pursue it anyway, driven by intellectual curiosity or moral duty.

Class Features

Hit Points

  • Hit Dice: 1d8 per Scholar level
  • Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
  • Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per Scholar level after 1st

Proficiencies

  • Armor: Light armor
  • Weapons: Simple weapons
  • Tools: None
  • Saving Throws: Intelligence, Wisdom
  • Skills: Choose three from Arcana, History, Insight, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Religion

Equipment

  • (a) a quarterstaff or (b) a dagger
  • (a) a scholar's pack or (b) an explorer's pack
  • A book on the subject of your expertise, a bottle of ink, an ink pen, 10 sheets of parchment

Class Features

Field of Study

At 1st level, choose your field of expertise: Natural Philosophy or Historical Research. Your field grants you features at 1st level and again at 3rd, 6th, and 14th level.

Scholar's Insight

Also at 1st level, your extensive studies grant you unusual knowledge. Choose two skills from Arcana, History, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, and Religion. You gain proficiency in those skills. If you are already proficient in a skill, you instead gain expertise in it (your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check using that skill).

Academic Support

Starting at 2nd level, you can inspire others through your knowledge and insight. To do so, you use a bonus action on your turn to choose one creature other than yourself within 60 feet of you who can hear you. That creature gains one Academic die, a d6.

Once within the next 10 minutes, the creature can roll the die and add the number rolled to one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw it makes. The creature can wait until after it rolls the d20 before deciding to use the Academic die, but must decide before the GM says whether the roll succeeds or fails. Once the Academic die is rolled, it is lost.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain any expended uses when you finish a long rest. Your Academic die changes when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Academic Dice column.

Ability Score Improvement

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1.

Font of Inspiration

Beginning when you reach 5th level, you regain all of your expended uses of Academic Support when you finish a short or long rest. The size of your Academic dice increases to d8 at 5th level, d10 at 10th level, and d12 at 15th level.

Expertise

At 10th level, choose two of your skill proficiencies. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

Superior Inspiration

At 20th level, when you roll initiative and have no uses of Academic Support left, you regain one use.

Fields of Study

Natural Philosophy

"Magic is a science waiting to be understood."

Natural Philosophers study the fundamental laws governing magic, nature, and reality. They might research at Shiz University, analyze Animal consciousness, or attempt to decode the Grimmerie. Like Dr. Dillamond, they seek objective truth—which can be very dangerous in Oz.

Arcane Analysis

When you choose this field at 1st level, you learn two cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these cantrips.

Scientific Method

Also at 1st level, when you make an Intelligence (Arcana) or Intelligence (Nature) check, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

Cutting Words

At 3rd level, you learn how to use your wit to distract, confuse, and otherwise sap the confidence and competence of others. When a creature that you can see within 60 feet of you makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a damage roll, you can use your reaction to expend one use of your Academic Support, rolling an Academic die and subtracting the number rolled from the creature's roll.

Counterspell Expert

At 6th level, you can cast *counterspell* once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you use *counterspell* in this way, you can add your Intelligence modifier to the ability check.

Theorist's Insight

At 14th level, when you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose one creature within 60 feet of you that is concentrating on a spell. That creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC or lose concentration on their spell.

Historical Research

"Those who control the past control the future."

Historical Researchers study Oz's past—including the parts the government wants forgotten. They document the Quadling Genocide, preserve pre-Unionist traditions, and maintain the truth against official propaganda. This work is essential but perilous.

Historical Expertise

When you choose this field at 1st level, you gain proficiency in History. If you are already proficient in History, you gain expertise in it instead. Additionally, you learn to read, write, and speak two additional languages of your choice.

Keen Mind

Also at 1st level, you have advantage on Intelligence checks to recall information about historical events, legendary people, ancient kingdoms, past disputes, recent wars, and lost civilizations.

Tales of Inspiration

Starting at 3rd level, when you use your Academic Support feature, you can speak of historical heroes and their deeds. The recipient of your Academic die gains temporary hit points equal to the number rolled + your Intelligence modifier.

Historian's Warning

At 6th level, you can use your reaction when you or a creature you can see within 30 feet is about to make a saving throw to grant them advantage on the roll, as you recall historical precedent for overcoming similar dangers. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

Master Researcher

At 14th level, when you spend at least 1 hour researching a topic in a library, archive, or similar repository of knowledge, you automatically learn any information that is recorded there about that topic, no roll required. Additionally, you can perfectly recall any text you have read in the past month.

Multiclassing

To qualify for a new class, you must have an Intelligence score of 13 or higher.

If Scholar isn't your initial class, you gain proficiency with light armor and two skills from the class's skill list.

Roleplaying a Scholar

Dangerous Knowledge

As a Scholar in Oz, you pursue knowledge that others fear. Consider:

  • What forbidden topic drives your research?
  • Have you published under your own name or anonymously?
  • What would you risk to preserve an important truth?
  • How do you feel about state-controlled education?

Teacher or Researcher

Scholars might focus on teaching (inspiring others with knowledge) or pure research (discovering new truths). Both paths matter in Oz's fight for truth.

GM Notes

Scholars as Support

Scholars excel at supporting allies through Academic Support, making them valuable party members even without combat magic.

Research-Based Adventures

Scholar PCs create natural hooks for research-based quests: finding lost texts, interviewing survivors, accessing forbidden archives, or proving historical truths.

character/classes/the-soldier.title: The Soldier
character/classes/the-soldier.content:
The Soldier

"I follow orders. But whose orders matter."

Soldiers are professional warriors serving in the Wizard's armies, regional militias, or resistance forces like the Gale Force. Whether enforcing the state's will or fighting against tyranny, Soldiers are defined by discipline, martial skill, and the weight of the violence they've committed in service to a cause. In Oz's constant low-level conflicts—border skirmishes, anti-Animal pogroms, resistance actions—Soldiers are both necessary and tragic figures.

Warriors and Veterans

Oz's military includes conscripts and volunteers, loyalists and doubters, heroes and war criminals. Some Soldiers believe in their cause. Others simply survive. All carry scars, both visible and invisible, from the battles they've fought.

Class Features

Hit Points

  • Hit Dice: 1d10 per Soldier level
  • Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
  • Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per Soldier level after 1st

Proficiencies

  • Armor: All armor, shields
  • Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
  • Tools: None
  • Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
  • Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Animal Handling, Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, Survival

Equipment

  • (a) chain mail or (b) leather armor, longbow, and 20 arrows
  • (a) a martial weapon and a shield or (b) two martial weapons
  • (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) two handaxes
  • (a) a dungeoneer's pack or (b) an explorer's pack

Class Features

Fighting Style

You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once.

  • Archery: +2 bonus to attack rolls with ranged weapons
  • Defense: +1 bonus to AC while wearing armor
  • Dueling: +2 bonus to damage rolls when wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons
  • Great Weapon Fighting: Reroll 1s and 2s on damage dice with two-handed melee weapons
  • Protection: Impose disadvantage on attack rolls against allies within 5 feet (requires shield)
  • Two-Weapon Fighting: Add ability modifier to damage of off-hand attacks

Second Wind

You have a limited well of stamina. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your Soldier level. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

Action Surge

Starting at 2nd level, you can push yourself beyond your normal limits. On your turn, you can take one additional action. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Starting at 17th level, you can use it twice before a rest.

Martial Archetype

At 3rd level, choose an archetype: Champion or Tactician. Your choice grants you features at 3rd, 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level.

Ability Score Improvement

When you reach 4th level, and again at 6th, 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score by 2, or two ability scores by 1.

Extra Attack

Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level and to four when you reach 20th level.

Indomitable

Beginning at 9th level, you can reroll a saving throw that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll. You can use this feature once, and you regain expended uses when you finish a long rest. You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 13th level and three times between long rests starting at 17th level.

Martial Archetypes

Champion

"I am the weapon my commanders forged."

Champions are elite warriors, whether serving the state or the resistance. They excel at direct combat and physical prowess.

Improved Critical

Beginning at 3rd level, your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

Remarkable Athlete

Starting at 7th level, you can add half your proficiency bonus (rounded up) to any Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution check you make that doesn't already use your proficiency bonus. Additionally, when you make a running long jump, the distance you can cover increases by a number of feet equal to your Strength modifier.

Additional Fighting Style

At 10th level, you can choose a second option from the Fighting Style class feature.

Superior Critical

Starting at 15th level, your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 18-20.

Survivor

At 18th level, you attain the pinnacle of resilience in battle. At the start of each of your turns, you regain hit points equal to 5 + your Constitution modifier if you have no more than half of your hit points left. You don't gain this benefit if you have 0 hit points.

Tactician

"Victory comes not from strength, but from strategy."

Tacticians are battlefield commanders, coordinating allies and outmaneuvering enemies through superior strategy.

Combat Superiority

At 3rd level, you learn maneuvers fueled by special dice called superiority dice. You learn three maneuvers and have four superiority dice (d8s). You can expend these dice to fuel various maneuvers. You regain all expended superiority dice when you finish a short or long rest.

Choose three from: Disarming Attack, Distracting Strike, Evasive Footwork, Feinting Attack, Goading Attack, Maneuvering Attack, Menacing Attack, Precision Attack, Pushing Attack, Rally, Riposte, Sweeping Attack, Trip Attack.

Student of War

At 3rd level, you gain proficiency with one type of artisan's tools of your choice.

Know Your Enemy

Starting at 7th level, if you spend at least 1 minute observing or interacting with another creature outside combat, you can learn certain information about its capabilities compared to yours (GM chooses two characteristics to compare).

Improved Combat Superiority

At 10th level, your superiority dice turn into d10s. At 18th level, they turn into d12s.

Additional Maneuvers

At 10th level, you learn two additional maneuvers. At 15th level, you learn two more.

Relentless

Starting at 15th level, when you roll initiative and have no superiority dice remaining, you regain 1 superiority die.

Multiclassing

To qualify for a new class, you must have a Strength or Dexterity score of 13 or higher.

If Soldier isn't your initial class, you gain proficiency with light armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, and martial weapons.

Roleplaying a Soldier

The Burden of Service

As a Soldier, consider:

  • Who did you fight for? Do you still believe in that cause?
  • What's the worst thing you did while following orders?
  • Have you killed anyone you regret killing?
  • What would make you disobey a direct command?

GM Notes

Soldiers in Oz

The Wizard's military enforces oppression, while resistance forces fight tyranny. Soldier PCs must grapple with the moral weight of violence in unjust conflicts.

Related Pages

  • The Wizard - Commander-in-chief
  • The Gale Force - Resistance fighters

character/classes/the-artisan.title: The Artisan
character/classes/the-artisan.content:
The Artisan

"I build the world I want to see."

Artisans are craftspeople, inventors, and tinkers who create both mundane and magical items. From the clockwork makers who built the Tiktoks to village blacksmiths forging plow shares into weapons for the resistance, Artisans shape Oz through their creations. In a land where magic and technology intertwine, those who understand both wield tremendous practical power.

Makers and Menders

Artisans might specialize in metalwork, alchemy, clockwork mechanisms, or magical item creation. Some work in state factories. Others maintain independence as guild members or traveling tinkers. All understand that what they create—and for whom—carries moral weight.

Class Features

Hit Points

  • Hit Dice: 1d8 per Artisan level
  • Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
  • Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per Artisan level after 1st

  • Armor: Light armor, medium armor
  • Weapons: Simple weapons
  • Tools: Thieves' tools, tinker's tools, one other artisan's tool of your choice
  • Saving Throws: Intelligence, Constitution
  • Skills: Choose two from Arcana, History, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Sleight of Hand

  • Any two simple weapons
  • A light crossbow and 20 bolts
  • Studded leather armor
  • Thieves' tools and a dungeoneer's pack

Class Features

Magical Tinkering

At 1st level, you learn how to invest a spark of magic into mundane objects. Whenever you finish a long rest, you can touch one nonmagical object and imbue it with one of the following effects: light, recorded message, odor, or nonverbal sound. The chosen property lasts indefinitely.

Spellcasting

You study the workings of magic and how to channel it through objects. You have a limited spellcasting ability. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability.

Infuse Item

At 2nd level, you gain the ability to imbue mundane items with magical infusions. You learn four infusions of your choice. Whenever you gain a level, you can replace one infusion you know with a new one. You can infuse two items, increasing at higher levels.

Artisan Specialty

At 3rd level, choose your specialty: Alchemist or Battle Smith. Your specialty grants features at 3rd, 5th, 9th, and 15th level.

The Right Tool for the Job

At 3rd level, you can produce any artisan's tools with 1 hour of work (returns to raw materials after use).

Tool Expertise

At 6th level, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses your proficiency with a tool.

Magic Item Adept

At 10th level, you can attune to up to four magic items at once, and crafting magic items takes you a quarter of the normal time.

Magic Item Savant

At 14th level, you can attune to up to five magic items at once, and you ignore all class, race, and level requirements on attuning to or using a magic item.

Soul of Artifice

At 20th level, your understanding of magic items is unmatched. You gain a +1 bonus to all saving throws per magic item you are currently attuned to, and if you're reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can use your reaction to end one of your infusions, dropping to 1 hit point instead.

Artisan Specialties

Alchemist

"Through chemistry, I remake the world."

Alchemists create potions, elixirs, and experimental substances, blending science and magic.

Tool Proficiency

At 3rd level, you gain proficiency with alchemist's supplies. If you already have this proficiency, you gain proficiency with one other type of artisan's tools.

Alchemist Spells

Starting at 3rd level, you always have certain spells prepared: healing word, ray of sickness (3rd); flaming sphere, melf's acid arrow (5th); gaseous form, mass healing word (9th); blight, death ward (13th); cloudkill, raise dead (17th).

Experimental Elixir

At 3rd level, whenever you finish a long rest, you can magically produce an experimental elixir in an empty flask. Roll on a table to determine the elixir's effect. As an action, a creature can drink the elixir or administer it to another creature. Creating an additional elixir requires expending a spell slot of 1st level or higher.

Alchemical Savant

At 5th level, whenever you cast a spell using alchemist's supplies as the spellcasting focus, you gain a bonus to one roll of the spell equal to your Intelligence modifier.

Restorative Reagents

At 9th level, you can cast *lesser restoration* using alchemist's supplies without expending a spell slot, and you can administer an experimental elixir as a bonus action.

Chemical Mastery

At 15th level, you gain resistance to acid and poison damage and immunity to the poisoned condition. You can cast *greater restoration* and *heal* without expending a spell slot, each once per long rest.

Battle Smith

"I forge both weapons and warriors."

Battle Smiths create weapons, armor, and mechanical defenders.

Tool Proficiency

At 3rd level, you gain proficiency with smith's tools.

Battle Ready

At 3rd level, you gain proficiency with martial weapons and can use Intelligence instead of Strength or Dexterity for attack and damage rolls with magic weapons.

Steel Defender

At 3rd level, you learn to create a Steel Defender, a mechanical construct. It obeys your commands and shares your initiative in combat.

Extra Attack

At 5th level, you can attack twice whenever you take the Attack action.

Arcane Jolt

At 9th level, when you or your defender hits a target with a magic weapon attack, you can channel magical energy to deal an extra 2d6 force damage or restore 2d6 hit points to a creature within 30 feet. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier.

Improved Defender

At 15th level, your Steel Defender's attacks are magical and deal an extra 1d8 force damage.

Multiclassing

To qualify for a new class, you must have an Intelligence score of 13 or higher. If Artisan isn't your initial class, you gain proficiency with light armor and one type of artisan's tools.

character/classes/the-traveler.title: The Traveler
character/classes/the-traveler.content:
The Traveler

"The wild places remember what civilization forgets."

Travelers are wanderers, scouts, and wilderness survivors who know the secret paths through the Vinkus steppes, the hidden routes across the Deadly Desert, and the safe ways through the Great Gillikin forests. They guide refugees, track fugitives, hunt for survival, and maintain connections to the land that urban Ozians have lost. In a nation crossed by borders and surveillance, Travelers know how to move unseen.

Guides and Guardians

Some Travelers work for the government as scouts and trackers. Others guide escapees along the Animal Underground Railroad. All possess deep knowledge of Oz's wild places and the creatures—both Animal and beast—that dwell there.

Class Features

Hit Points

  • Hit Dice: 1d10 per Traveler level
  • Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
  • Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per Traveler level after 1st

Proficiencies

  • Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
  • Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
  • Tools: None
  • Saving Throws: Strength, Dexterity
  • Skills: Choose three from Animal Handling, Athletics, Insight, Investigation, Nature, Perception, Stealth, Survival

Equipment

  • (a) scale mail or (b) leather armor
  • (a) two shortswords or (b) two simple melee weapons
  • (a) a dungeoneer's pack or (b) an explorer's pack
  • A longbow and a quiver of 20 arrows

Class Features

Favored Enemy

At 1st level, choose a type of favored enemy: beasts, fey, humanoids, or monstrosities. You have advantage on Survival checks to track your favored enemies and on Intelligence checks to recall information about them. You learn one language spoken by your favored enemies.

You choose one additional favored enemy at 6th and 14th level.

Natural Explorer

You are a master of navigating the natural world. Choose one type of favored terrain: arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, mountain, or swamp. When you make an Intelligence or Wisdom check related to your favored terrain, your proficiency bonus is doubled. While traveling for an hour or more in your favored terrain, you gain several benefits including difficult terrain doesn't slow your group's travel, your group can't become lost, you remain alert to danger even when engaged in other activities, you can move stealthily at a normal pace when traveling alone, and you find twice as much food and water when you forage.

You choose additional favored terrain types at 6th and 10th level.

Fighting Style

At 2nd level, choose a fighting style: Archery, Defense, Dueling, or Two-Weapon Fighting.

Spellcasting

Starting at 2nd level, you learn ranger spells. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability.

Traveler Archetype

At 3rd level, choose your archetype: Hunter or Beastmaster. Your choice grants features at 3rd, 7th, 11th, and 15th level.

Primeval Awareness

At 3rd level, you can use your action and expend one spell slot to focus your awareness on the region around you. For 1 minute per level of the spell slot you expend, you can sense whether certain types of creatures are present within 1 mile of you (or within up to 6 miles if you are in your favored terrain).

Extra Attack

Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice whenever you take the Attack action.

Land's Stride

Starting at 8th level, moving through nonmagical difficult terrain costs you no extra movement. You can also pass through nonmagical plants without being slowed and without taking damage from thorns, spines, and similar hazards.

Hide in Plain Sight

At 10th level, you can spend 1 minute creating camouflage for yourself. Once camouflaged, you can hide against a solid surface and gain a +10 bonus to Dexterity (Stealth) checks as long as you remain there without moving or taking actions.

Vanish

Starting at 14th level, you can use the Hide action as a bonus action. Also, you can't be tracked by nonmagical means unless you choose to leave a trail.

Feral Senses

At 18th level, you gain preternatural senses. You can't be surprised while you are conscious. You are aware of invisible creatures within 30 feet of you, provided they aren't hidden from you and you aren't blinded or deafened.

Foe Slayer

At 20th level, once per turn when you hit a favored enemy with an attack, you can add your Wisdom modifier to the attack's damage.

Traveler Archetypes

Hunter

"I know every track, every trail, every hiding place."

Hunters specialize in tracking and eliminating specific prey—whether beasts threatening settlements or fugitives fleeing justice.

Hunter's Prey

At 3rd level, choose one feature: Colossus Slayer (extra 1d8 damage once per turn to wounded creatures), Giant Killer (reaction attack when Large+ creature attacks you), or Horde Breaker (attack additional creature within 5 ft of first target).

Defensive Tactics

At 7th level, choose one feature: Escape the Horde (opportunity attacks against you have disadvantage), Multiattack Defense (+4 AC against subsequent attacks from same creature), or Steel Will (advantage on saves against being frightened).

Multiattack

At 11th level, choose one feature: Volley (ranged attack against all creatures in 10-ft radius), or Whirlwind Attack (melee attack against all creatures within 5 feet).

Superior Hunter's Defense

At 15th level, choose one feature: Evasion, Stand Against the Tide (redirect missed melee attack to another creature), or Uncanny Dodge.

Beastmaster

"The beasts of Oz are my companions, not my servants."

Beastmasters form deep bonds with animal companions, working in partnership with creatures of the wild.

Ranger's Companion

At 3rd level, you gain a beast companion of Medium or smaller size with a challenge rating of 1/4 or lower. The companion obeys your commands and shares your initiative.

Exceptional Training

At 7th level, your companion can use its reaction to make a melee attack when you command it using your bonus action.

Bestial Fury

At 11th level, your companion can make two attacks when you command it to attack.

Share Spells

At 15th level, when you cast a spell targeting yourself, you can also affect your beast companion if it's within 30 feet.

Multiclassing

To qualify for a new class, you must have Dexterity and Wisdom scores of 13 or higher. If Traveler isn't your initial class, you gain proficiency with light armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, martial weapons, and one skill from the class list.

character/classes/the-performer.title: The Performer
character/classes/the-performer.content:
The Performer

"The stage is truth told through beautiful lies."

Performers are artists, musicians, actors, and storytellers who wield charisma as their instrument. In Oz's authoritarian regime, entertainment serves many purposes—state propaganda at official theaters, subtle resistance through satirical shows, or simple distraction from daily oppression. Whether headlining at Emerald City opera houses or singing rebellious ballads in Munchkinland taverns, Performers understand that art can inspire, deceive, and even change minds.

Artists and Provocateurs

Some Performers work as state-approved entertainers, carefully avoiding political content. Others use their art to smuggle forbidden ideas to audiences. Still others serve as spies, using performance as cover for intelligence gathering. All understand that in Oz, what you say matters less than how you say it—and to whom.

Class Features

Hit Points

  • Hit Dice: 1d8 per Performer level
  • Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
  • Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per Performer level after 1st

Proficiencies

  • Armor: Light armor
  • Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers, shortswords
  • Tools: Three musical instruments of your choice
  • Saving Throws: Dexterity, Charisma
  • Skills: Choose any three

Equipment

  • (a) a rapier, (b) a longsword, or (c) any simple weapon
  • (a) a diplomat's pack or (b) an entertainer's pack
  • (a) a lute or (b) any other musical instrument
  • Leather armor and a dagger

Class Features

Spellcasting

You have learned to channel magic through music, words, and gesture. Charisma is your spellcasting ability. You can use a musical instrument as a spellcasting focus.

Performance Inspiration

You can inspire others through stirring words or music. As a bonus action, choose one creature within 60 feet who can hear you. That creature gains one Inspiration die (d6). Once within the next 10 minutes, the creature can roll the die and add the number to one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), regaining expended uses on a long rest. The die becomes d8 at 5th level, d10 at 10th level, and d12 at 15th level.

Jack of All Trades

Starting at 2nd level, you can add half your proficiency bonus (rounded down) to any ability check you make that doesn't already include your proficiency bonus.

Song of Rest

Beginning at 2nd level, during a short rest, you or any friendly creatures who hear your performance regain extra hit points equal to a d6 + your Charisma modifier. This die increases to d8 at 9th level, d10 at 13th level, and d12 at 17th level.

Performance Style

At 3rd level, choose your style: Glamour (enchanting beauty and fey magic) or Satire (cutting words and mockery). Your style grants features at 3rd, 6th, and 14th level.

Expertise

At 3rd level, choose two skill proficiencies. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for ability checks using those skills. At 10th level, choose two more.

Ability Score Improvement

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score by 2, or two ability scores by 1.

Font of Inspiration

Beginning at 5th level, you regain all expended uses of Performance Inspiration when you finish a short or long rest.

Countercharm

At 6th level, you can use musical notes or words of power to disrupt mind-influencing effects. As an action, you can perform, and any friendly creatures within 30 feet have advantage on saving throws against being frightened or charmed until the start of your next turn.

Magical Secrets

At 10th level, you learn two spells from any class. At 14th level, you learn two more, and at 18th level, you learn two more. These count as Performer spells for you.

Superior Inspiration

At 20th level, when you roll initiative and have no uses of Performance Inspiration left, you regain one use.

Performance Styles

Glamour

"Beauty is a spell, and I am its caster."

Glamour Performers channel fey magic through their art, captivating audiences with supernatural beauty and charm.

Mantle of Inspiration

At 3rd level, as a bonus action, you can expend one use of your Performance Inspiration. When you do, choose a number of creatures you can see within 60 feet equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one). Each gains 5 temporary hit points and can immediately use its reaction to move up to its speed. The temporary hit points increase to 8 at 5th level, 11 at 10th level, and 14 at 15th level.

Enthralling Performance

At 6th level, you can charge your performance with magic. If you perform for at least 1 minute, you can attempt to inspire wonder. At the end of the performance, choose a number of humanoids within 60 feet equal to your Charisma modifier. Each must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be charmed by you for 1 hour. While charmed, the creature idolizes you and speaks highly of you. This effect ends if the creature takes damage or witnesses you or your companions doing anything harmful to it. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

Unbreakable Majesty

At 14th level, as a bonus action, you can assume a magically majestic presence for 1 minute. For the duration, whenever a creature tries to attack you for the first time on a turn, it must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failure, it can't attack you on this turn and must choose a new target or lose the attack. On a success, it can attack but has disadvantage on all saves against your spells on your next turn. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

Satire

"I speak truth to power—and make them laugh while doing it."

Satirical Performers use mockery, wit, and cutting words as weapons against tyranny and pretension.

Cutting Words

At 3rd level, when a creature you can see within 60 feet makes an attack roll, ability check, or damage roll, you can use your reaction to expend one use of Performance Inspiration, rolling the die and subtracting the number from the creature's roll. You can use this after seeing the roll but before knowing whether it succeeds or fails.

Additional Magical Secrets

At 6th level, you learn two additional spells from any class. These count as Performer spells for you but don't count against your number of spells known.

Peerless Skill

At 14th level, when you make an ability check, you can expend one use of Performance Inspiration, rolling the die and adding it to your ability check. You can do this after seeing the roll but before knowing whether you succeed or fail.

Multiclassing

To qualify for a new class, you must have a Charisma score of 13 or higher. If Performer isn't your initial class, you gain proficiency with light armor and one skill of your choice, plus one musical instrument of your choice.

Roleplaying a Performer

Art and Politics

As a Performer in Oz, consider:

  • Do you perform state-approved material or subversive art?
  • Have you ever been censored? How did you respond?
  • What message do you want your art to convey?
  • Do you see yourself as entertainer or activist—or both?

GM Notes

Performance and Propaganda

In Oz's authoritarian state, all public performance is political. State theaters spread propaganda, while underground shows spread resistance messages.
